THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Eller Media Company and Ed Carver d/b/a Wallpapers by Lynne, Respondents/Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        City of North Myrtle Beach, Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Memorandum Opinion No. 2006-MO-038
Heard October 18, 2006 â€“ Filed November 13, 2006

VACATED AND DISMISSED 


  
    
      
        Michael W. Battle and Salley W. Peace, both of Battle & Vaught, P.A., of Conway, for Appellant/Respondent.
        Douglas M. Zayicek, of Bellamy, Rutenberg, Copeland, Epps, Gravely & Bowers, P.A., of Myrtle Beach, for Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  This cross-appeal concerns the validity and construction of zoning ordinances of the City of North Myrtle Beach (City).Â  The master-in-equity entered an order in favor of Eller Media Company (Eller Media) and Ed Carver, d/b/a Wallpapers by Lynne (Carver).Â  This Court certified the case for review from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We vacate and dismiss.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
 In 1989, Eller Media erected a billboard on property located on Highway 17 South in the City after obtaining sign permits from the State of South Carolina and the City.Â  The City subsequently enacted zoning ordinances which regulated in relevant part signs in the City and affected Eller Mediaâ€™s billboard.Â  
 In April of 1999, Carver bought the property on which Eller Mediaâ€™s billboard was located (hereinafter referred to as â€œCarverâ€™s propertyâ€).Â  Eller Media then executed a lease with Carver to maintain the billboard on Carverâ€™s property.Â  In January 2001, Carver submitted an application to the City for a sign permit for a freestanding, on-premise, business identification sign on his property.Â  The Cityâ€™s zoning administrator told Carver that his sign permit would be denied pursuant to the Cityâ€™s sign ordinances unless Eller Mediaâ€™s billboard was removed.Â  
Eller Media filed this declaratory judgment action against the City.Â  Eller Media sought temporary and permanent injunctions, which would prohibit the City from enforcing its sign ordinances against Eller Media.Â  In the alternative, Eller Media requested just compensation for a taking.Â  The circuit court granted Eller Mediaâ€™s motion for temporary injunction.Â  
The City then granted Carver a permit for a freestanding, on-premise sign.Â  Carver was subsequently added as a plaintiff in this action, and in their amended complaint, Eller Media and Carver continued to seek a permanent injunction.Â  The City counterclaimed and requested a court order requiring Carver to remove his sign.
The master-in-equity permanently enjoined the City from enforcing its sign ordinances against Eller Media and Carver.Â  The master-in-equity found the plain language of the Cityâ€™s sign ordinances allowed Eller Mediaâ€™s billboard and Carverâ€™s freestanding, on-premise, business identification sign to be on the same property.Â  The master also ruled state law preempted the Cityâ€™s sign ordinances and state law allowed both signs.Â  Additionally, the master-in-equity found the City was estopped from revoking Carverâ€™s permit.
The City appealed and raised the following issues:

  
    I. 
    Did the master-in-equity err in finding the City’s sign ordinances conflict with and are thus preempted by state law?  
  
  
    II. 
    Did the master-in-equity err in construing the City’s sign   ordinances to allow a freestanding, on-premise, business identification sign and a billboard on the same property?  
  
  
    II. 
    Did the master-in-equity err in estopping the City from revoking Carver’s sign permit?  
  

 Eller Media and Carver cross-appealed and raised the following issue:

  
    I. 
    Did the master-in-equity err in addressing constitutional issues?  
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
Generally, this Court may only consider cases where a justiciable controversy exists.Â  Byrd v. Irmo High Sch., 321 S.C. 426, 430, 468 S.E.2d 861, 864 (1996).Â  A justiciable controversy is a real and substantial controversy which is ripe and appropriate for judicial determination, as distinguished from a contingent, hypothetical or abstract dispute.Â  An adjudication that would not settle the legal rights of the parties would only be advisory in nature and, therefore, would be beyond the intended purpose and scope of the Uniform Declaratory Judgments Act.Â  Sunset Cay, LLC v. City of Folly Beach, 357 S.C. 414, 423, 593 S.E.2d 462, 466 (2004).Â  The function of appellate courts is not to give opinions on merely abstract or theoretical matters, but only to decide actual controversies injuriously affecting the rights of some party to the litigation.Â  Accordingly, cases or issues which have become moot or academic in nature are not a proper subject of review.Â  Wallace v. City of York, 276 S.C. 693, 694, 281 S.E.2d 487, 488 (1981).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
We decline to address the issues before us because there is no justiciable controversy.Â  Eller Media and Carver both have sign permits from the City; Eller Media has a billboard on Carverâ€™s property and Carver has a sign on his property.Â  We find Eller Mediaâ€™s and Carverâ€™s request to enjoin the City from enforcing its sign ordinances to be moot. Â See Curtis v. State, 345 S.C. 557, 567, 549 S.E.2d 591, 596 (2001) (â€œA case becomes moot when judgment, if rendered, will have no practical legal effect upon [the] existing controversy.Â  This is true when some event occurs making it impossible for [the] reviewing Court to grant effectual relief.â€ (quoting Mathis v. S.C. State Hwy. Depâ€™t, 260 S.C. 344, 346, 195 S.E.2d 713, 715 (1973))).Â  We also find the Cityâ€™s request for a court order requiring Carter to remove his sign is not ripe.Â  See Park v. Safeco Ins. Co. of Am., 251 S.C. 410, 414, 162 S.E.2d 709, 711 (1968) (â€œThe courts generally decline to pronounce a declaration in a suit wherein the rights of the plaintiff are contingent upon the happening of some event which cannot be forecast and which may never take place.â€). 
CONCLUSION
We conclude there is no justiciable controversy before us.Â  We vacate the circuit courtâ€™s order granting a temporary injunction and the master-in-equityâ€™s order granting a permanent injunction and estopping the City from enforcing its sign ordinances, and we dismiss this case.
VACATED AND DISMISSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant was convicted of murder and was sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  His conviction and sentence were upheld on direct appeal.Â  State v. Brown, Op. No. 87-MO-164 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 30, 1987).Â  
Appellant filed a petition for a writ of habeas corpus, which was denied by the circuit court.Â  Counsel for appellant has now filed an appeal from the denial of the petition, along with a petition to be relieved as counsel.[1]Â  Appellant has filed a pro se response.Â  
The appeal is dismissed under Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, after consideration of appellantâ€™s pro se brief and review pursuant to Anders v. California, supra.Â  Counselâ€™s motion to be relieved is granted.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from the denial of his application for post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  We deny Questions II, III, and IV.
Because there is sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that petitioner did not knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we grant certiorari on Question I and proceed with a review of the direct appeal issue pursuant to Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).
Petitionerâ€™s conviction and sentence are affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authority: Boykin v. Alabama, 395 U.S. 238, 89 S.Ct. 1709, 23 L.Ed.2d 274 (1969).
AFFIRMED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
